query: What evidence exists for the effectiveness of different strategies to combat white-nose syndrome in bats?
relevant_summary: Two studies assessed the effectiveness of treating bats with a probiotic bacterium for white-nose syndrome (2008). In a Canadian laboratory study, little brown bats treated with the probiotic at the time of infection showed increased survival, while those treated 21 days prior to infection experienced worse symptoms (2008). A study in the USA found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic in a mine increased survival for free-flying bats, but not for those in cages (2008). The US study also found that the severity of white-nose syndrome in caged bats treated with a probiotic was similar to untreated bats (2008). No studies were found that evaluated the effectiveness of breeding bats in captivity to supplement wild populations affected by white-nose syndrome (2009) or the effects of decontaminating clothing and equipment after entering caves to reduce the spread of the pathogen on bat populations (2006).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"effectiveness of strategies to combat white-nose syndrome in bats"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "2008",
  "action_title": "Treat bats for infection with white-nose syndrome",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies evaluated the effects of treating bats with a probiotic bacterium to reduce white-nose syndrome infection. One study was in Canada and one in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Survival (2 studies): One randomized, controlled study in Canada found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium at the time of infection with white-nose syndrome (but not 21 days prior) increased survival within cages in a laboratory. One randomized, controlled study in the USA found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium within a mine increased survival for free-flying bats, but not caged bats.
Condition (2 studies): One randomized, controlled study in Canada found that little brown bats caged in a laboratory and treated with a probiotic bacterium at the time of infection with white-nose syndrome had reduced symptoms of the disease, but bats treated 21 days prior to infection had worse symptoms. One randomized, controlled study in the USA found that little brown bats kept within cages in a mine and treated with a probiotic bacterium had a similar severity of white-nose syndrome to untreated bats.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

The US study also found that the severity of white-nose syndrome in caged bats treated with a probiotic was similar to untreated bats (2008). No studies were found that evaluated the effectiveness of breeding bats in captivity to supplement wild populations affected by white-nose syndrome (2009) or the effects of decontaminating clothing and equipment after entering caves to reduce the spread of the pathogen on bat populations (2006)."}

query: To mitigate the impact of road and railway developments, what structures can be installed to help bats cross safely?
relevant_summary:
Eight studies in Europe and Australia found that bats used underpasses and culverts to cross below roads (976). The usage of these structures by five bat species was found to be influenced by the underpass type and height, the width of the road, and the amount of forest and hedgerows in the surrounding landscape (976). One study in Australia also found that bat species adapted to cluttered habitats used small culverts and underpasses more than species adapted to open or edge habitats (976).

Four studies in Europe and Australia have evaluated the installation of overpasses as road crossing structures for bats (977). One study found that an overpass with planters was used by two-thirds of crossing bats, while an unvegetated overpass was not used (977). Two other studies found that some bat species used overpasses, but up to three-quarters of bats crossed the road at traffic height or at other nearby locations (977). One study found the same number of bat species at an overpass as in nearby forest and bushland (977).

There were no studies found that evaluated the effects of hop-overs as road or railway crossing structures for bats (980).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"structures for bats to cross roads and railways safely"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "976",
  "action_title": "Install underpasses or culverts as road/railway crossing structures for bats",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Eight studies evaluated the effects of installing underpasses or culverts as road crossing structures for bats. Seven studies were in Europe and one in Australia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (8 STUDIES)      

Use (8 studies): Eight studies (including six replicated studies) in Germany, Ireland, the UK, Australia and France found that bats used underpasses and culverts below roads, and crossed over the roads above them, in varying proportions. One replicated, site comparison study in Australia found that bat species adapted to cluttered habitats used small culverts and underpasses more than bat species adapted to open or edge habitats. One replicated, site comparison study in France found that the use of underpasses by five bat species was influenced by underpass type and height, road width, and the amount of forest and hedgerows in the surrounding landscape."
}

{
  "action_id": "977",
  "action_title": "Install overpasses as road/railway crossing structures for bats",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Four studies evaluated the effects of installing overpasses as road crossing structures for bats. Three studies were in Europe and one in Australia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): One site comparison study in Australia found that the same number of bat species were recorded at an overpass and in nearby forest and bushland.

POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (3 STUDIES)      

Use (3 studies): Two replicated studies (including one site comparison) in Ireland and France found that two or three bat species/species groups used overpasses but up to three-quarters of bats crossed the road below at traffic height or crossed at other nearby locations. One study in the UK found that an overpass with planters was used by two-thirds of crossing bats, and an unvegetated overpass with a paved road over it was not used by crossing bats."
}

query: How do different methods for restricting public access to bat hibernation sites, such as gates versus fences, compare in their effects on bat populations?
relevant_summary: One study found that significantly fewer bats emerged from a cave with a gate installed compared with a cave with a fence (999). Another study found that significantly more bats emerged from a cave after a steel gate was replaced with a fence (1991). When studying the effects of installing cave gates, three of four before-and-after studies found more or similar numbers of bats in caves after gates were installed to restrict public access, while one study found fewer bats (999). For fences, one replicated study found no difference in the population growth rates of bats roosting in caves with and without fencing or gates installed (1991). One study found that installing cave gates resulted in population increases or decreased rates of decline for 13 of 20 colonies of Indiana bat (999). However, another study found that bats hibernating in a cave with a wall and gate over the entrance lost more body mass than bats in a nearby unmodified cave (999). One replicated, controlled, before-and-after and site comparison study found that bats at cave entrances circled more and entered caves less after gates were installed (999).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"restricting public access to bat hibernation sites"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "999",
  "action_title": "Install and maintain cave gates to restrict public access",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Eleven studies evaluated the effects of installing cave gates on bat populations. Six studies were in the USA and five studies were in Europe.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (7 STUDIES)

Abundance (7 studies): Three of four before-and-after studies (including one replicated study and one controlled study) in the Netherlands, the USA, Spain and Turkey found more or similar numbers of bats in caves and a bunker after gates were installed to restrict public access. The other study found fewer bats in caves after gates were installed. Two before-and-after studies in the USA and Spain found more bats within two caves after the size of the gated entrances were increased. One replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that installing cave gates resulted in population increases or decreased rates of decline for 13 of 20 colonies of Indiana bat. One replicated, site comparison study in Spain found no difference in the population growth rates of bats roosting in caves with and without cave gates.
Condition (1 study): One site comparison study in the USA found that bats hibernating in a cave with a wall and gate over the entrance lost more body mass than bats in a nearby unmodified cave.

BEHAVIOUR (5 STUDIES)   

Use (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in Spain found no difference in the occupancy rates of bats roosting in caves with and without cave gates.
Behaviour change (4 studies): One replicated, controlled, before-and-after and site comparison study in the USA found that bats at cave entrances circled more and entered caves less after gates were installed. One replicated study in the USA found that bats flew through gates with a funnel design more frequently than gates with a round bar or angle iron design. One randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in the UK found that fewer bats flew through cave gates when the spacing between horizontal bars was reduced. One before-and-after study in the USA found that significantly fewer bats emerged from a cave with a gate installed compared with a cave with a fence."
}

query: To mitigate impacts from onshore wind farms, what are the most effective operational adjustments to turbines to reduce bat fatalities?
relevant_summary: Ten out of twelve studies in the USA and Canada found that increasing the wind speed at which turbines become operational, known as 'cut-in speed', or increasing the cut-in speed along with preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds ('feathering'), resulted in fewer bat fatalities compared to conventionally operated turbines (1960). Five of six studies in the USA and Canada found that 'feathering', which prevents turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds, or feathering along with increasing the cut-in speed, also resulted in fewer bat fatalities (970). One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Canada found that bat fatalities were reduced when turbine blades were slowed at low wind speeds (2939).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"operational adjustments to turbines to reduce bat fatalities"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "1960",
  "action_title": "Increase the wind speed at which turbines become operational (‘cut-in speed’)",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twelve studies evaluated the effects of increasing the wind speed at which turbines become operational (‘cut-in speed’) on bat populations. Ten studies were in the USA and two were in Canada.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (12 STUDIES)

Survival (12 studies): Ten of 12 studies (including 10 replicated, randomized, controlled studies and one before-and-after study) in the USA and Canada found that increasing the wind speed at which turbines become operational (‘cut-in speed’), or increasing the cut-in speed along with preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds (‘feathering’) resulted in fewer bat fatalities than at conventionally operated turbines. The other two studies found that increasing cut-in speeds did not reduce bat fatalities, but sample sizes were small or treatments were applied for short periods only.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

{
  "action_id": "2939",
  "action_title": "Slow rotation of turbine blades at low wind speeds",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One study evaluated the effects of slowing the rotation of turbine blades at low wind speeds on bat populations. The study was in Canada.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Survival (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Canada found that bat fatalities were reduced when turbine blades were slowed at low wind speeds.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

{
  "action_id": "970",
  "action_title": "Prevent turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds ('feathering')",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies evaluated the effects of preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds on bat populations. Five studies were in the USA and one was in Canada.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (6 STUDIES)

Survival (6 studies): Five of six studies (including five replicated, controlled studies and one before-and-after study) in the USA and Canada found that preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds (‘feathering’), or feathering along with increasing the wind speed at which turbines become operational (‘cut-in speed’) resulted in fewer bat fatalities than at conventionally operated turbines. The other study found that automatically feathering turbine blades at low wind speeds did not reduce bat fatalities.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

query: Instead of culling, what alternative non-lethal actions can be used to manage human-bat conflicts?
relevant_summary: Two replicated, controlled studies in Madagascar and Mauritius found that the use of an organic deterrent spray, hanging plastic flags in trees, or covering individual tree branches with nylon net bags reduced damage to lychees from Madagascan flying foxes or Mauritius fruit bats (1953). One of the studies also found that ringing bells in lychee trees was successful in deterring most Madagascan flying foxes (1953). No studies were discovered that assessed the effects of substituting bat culling with non-lethal approaches to stop vampire bats from transmitting rabies to people or livestock (1979, 1950).

One of the studies found that ringing bells in lychee trees deterred most Madagascan flying foxes."
}

query: How effective are different public education and engagement strategies for improving bat conservation outcomes?
relevant_summary: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of educating the public to improve the perception of bats to improve behaviour towards bats [1000]. One study in the UK found that during a five-year project to engage farmers and landowners to manage land for bats, the overall population of greater horseshoe bats at four maternity roosts in the area increased [1936]. The landowner engagement project resulted in 77 bat-related management agreements covering approximately 6,536 ha of land [1936].

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

Change in human behaviour (1 study): One study in the UK found that a landowner engagement project resulted in 77 bat-related management agreements covering approximately 6,536 ha of land."
}

query: Besides avoiding illumination entirely, what alternative lighting strategies can be used to minimize disturbance to bats?

relevant_summary.erroneous_summary:
One replicated, controlled, site comparison study in the Netherlands found that red lighting resulted in higher activity for one of three bat species groups than white or green lighting (2021). Another study in the Netherlands found that culverts illuminated with red light had similar activity of commuting Daubenton’s bats as culverts illuminated with white or green light (2021). One replicated, controlled study in the UK found that more soprano pipistrelles emerged from a roost when lit with red light than when lit with white light, but no difference was found between red and blue lights (2021). 

One controlled study in the USA found that using low intensity white lights or red lights in caves resulted in fewer bat flights than with full white lighting (1994). 

No studies were found that evaluated the effects on bat populations of using ‘warm white’ rather than ‘cool’ LED lights (2020).

query: To protect bats from the impacts of mining operations, what actions can be taken during and after mine closure and reclamation?
relevant_summary: For the actions of excluding bats from roosts prior to mine reclamation (1961) and retaining access points for bats following mine closures (1962), no studies were found that evaluated their effects on bat populations (1961, 1962). Nine studies have evaluated the effects of installing gates at mine entrances (1963). One study in the USA found that fewer bat species entered mines after gates were installed, and two studies in the USA and Australia found fewer bats in mines or at mine entrances after gate installation (1963). However, another study in the USA found that bat activity remained stable or increased at five of seven gated mines, while decreasing at two (1963). In terms of bat behavior, one study found that 43 of 47 mines were still used 12 years after gates were installed, but bats abandoned four mines with 'ladder' design gates (1963). Four studies in the USA and Australia noted that bats at mine entrances circled more and entered mines less after gates were installed (1963). Additionally, one study in the USA found that up to 7% of bats at mine entrances collided with mine gates (1963).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"protect bats from mining operations during and after mine closure and reclamation"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "1963",
  "action_title": "Install and maintain gates at mine entrances to restrict public access",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Nine studies evaluated the effects of installing gates at mine entrances on bat populations. Eight studies were in the USA and one in Australia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): One replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that fewer bat species entered mines after gates were installed.

POPULATION RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Abundance (3 studies): Two replicated, site comparison or before-and-after studies in the USA and Australia found fewer bats in mines or at mine entrances after gates were installed. One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that bat activity (relative abundance) remained stable or increased at five of seven gated mines, and decreased at two gated mines.

BEHAVIOUR (6 STUDIES)      

Use (2 studies): One before-and-after study in the USA found that 43 of 47 mines continued to be used 12 years after gates were installed, however bats abandoned four mines with ‘ladder’ design gates. One replicated study in the USA found that gate design and time since gate installation had varied effects on the presence of four bat species.
Behaviour change (4 studies): Four replicated, before-and-after or site comparison studies in the USA and Australia found that bats at mine entrances circled more and entered mines less after gates were installed.

OTHER (2 STUDIES)

Collisions with gates (1 study): One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that up to 7% of bats at mine entrances collided with mine gates."
}

query: What are the most effective legislative actions for protecting bats and their habitats?
relevant_summary:
No studies were found that evaluated the effects of introducing and enforcing legislation to control the hunting of bats (984) or enforcing existing legislation for habitat protection (2916).

Five studies evaluated the effects of legally protecting bat habitats (2045). In terms of community response, one study in India found that bat species composition was similar in protected and unprotected forest fragments (2045). Two studies in Europe and India found no difference in the number of bat species between protected and unprotected forests, but one study in France found a greater number of bat species in protected sites (2045). Regarding population response, one study in the UK found higher activity of Daubenton's bats over rivers in protected areas (2045). Another study in Europe reported higher activity of common noctule bats in protected forests, but overall bat activity did not differ (2045). Two studies in France and India found higher overall bat activity and a greater number of bats in protected sites and forests (2045). In terms of behavior, a study in Spain revealed that the distributions of 10 out of 11 bat species overlapped significantly with their designated protected areas (2045).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"legislative actions for protecting bats and their habitats"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "2045",
  "action_title": "Legally protect bat habitats",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Five studies evaluated the effects of legally protecting bat habitats on bat populations. Four studies were in Europe and one was in India.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in India found that the composition of bat species was similar in protected forest and unprotected forest fragments.
Richness/diversity (2 studies): Two replicated, site comparison or paired sites studies in Europe and India found that the number of bat species did not differ between protected and unprotected forests or forest fragments. One replicated, site comparison study in France found that protected sites had a greater number of bat species than unprotected sites.

POPULATION RESPONSE (4 STUDIES)

Abundance (4 studies): One replicated, site comparison study in the UK found that the activity (relative abundance) of Daubenton’s bats was higher over rivers on farms in protected areas than in unprotected areas. One replicated, paired sites study in Europe found that the activity of common noctule bats was higher in protected forests than unprotected forests, but bat activity overall did not differ. Two replicated, site comparison studies in France and India found higher overall bat activity, higher activity of three of six bat species/species groups and a greater number of bats in protected sites and forests than unprotected sites and forests.

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)         

Use (1 study): One study in Spain found that the distributions of 10 of 11 bat species overlapped with areas designated to protect them significantly more than by chance."
}

query: For bat conservation related to transportation infrastructure, what are the documented benefits and limitations of providing or retaining roosts in bridges and culverts?
relevant_summary: One study in the USA found that creating spaces for roosting bats in road bridges to replace those lost during bridge works resulted in recolonization by bats in similar or greater numbers at four of eight sites (1967). Another study in Ireland showed that a maternity colony of Daubenton’s bats continued to roost in a road bridge in similar numbers after crevices were retained during repair work (1966). A review in the USA also found that when bat roosts were maintained during bridge replacement works, Yuma myotis and Mexican free-tailed bats recolonized most roosts in similar numbers to before the works (1966). However, the same review noted that pallid bats did not return to the maintained roosts (1966). Furthermore, a separate review in the USA found that bat houses provided as alternative roosts during bridge replacement works were used by fewer Mexican free-tailed bats than the original roost at one site and were not used by bats at all at three other sites (2942).

query: How does the evidence for managing existing hedgerows for bats compare to that for planting new ones?
relevant_summary: Two UK-based studies assessed how managing hedges affects bats (1943). One of these replicated, site comparison studies revealed that hedges trimmed three or more years ago had a higher number of bat species and greater activity for two of eight bat species or species groups when compared to hedges trimmed in the last winter (1943). A replicated, paired sites study discovered no significant difference in the activity of pipistrelle bats between hedges on farms in agri-environment schemes and those on conventional farms (1943). There were no studies found that assessed the impact of planting new hedges on bat populations (1942).

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in the UK found that hedges trimmed ≥3 years prior had more bat species recorded along them than hedges trimmed during the previous winter.

POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Abundance (2 studies): One replicated, paired sites study in the UK found that pipistrelle activity (relative abundance) did not differ between hedges managed for wildlife on agri-environment scheme farms and hedges on conventional farms. One replicated, site comparison study in the UK found that hedges trimmed ≥3 years prior had higher activity of two of eight bat species/species groups than hedges trimmed during the previous winter.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

query: What actions can be taken to provide bat roosting sites in trees where natural cavities are lacking?
relevant_summary: Action 95 suggests providing bat boxes, bat grilles, or making improvements to roosts, though no evidence was found regarding their effects on farmland wildlife (95). Similarly, Action 993 proposes retaining veteran and standing dead trees as roosting sites for bats, but no studies have evaluated the effects of this on bat populations (993). A study in the UK, as noted in Action 2048, showed that a bat roost reinstated by attaching a felled tree trunk to a nearby tree continued to be used by common noctule bats as a maternity roost (2048).

query: How does the evidence for legally protecting bat habitats compare to legally protecting bats during development activities?
relevant_summary:
Five studies evaluated the effect of legally protecting bat habitats, with four in Europe and one in India (2045). Of these, two studies in Europe and India found that the number of bat species did not differ between protected and unprotected forests, but one study in France found more bat species in protected sites (2045). Bat activity and abundance were found to be higher in protected areas in multiple studies (2045). One study in Spain also found that the distributions of 10 of 11 bat species significantly overlapped with areas designated for their protection (2045).

In comparison, four studies in the UK evaluated the effects of legally protecting bats during development by issuing licenses (1935). These studies found that licensed development activities had a negative impact on bat roosts, with one review finding 68% of roosts were destroyed (1935). Other studies found that compensation roosts were not always used by bats, with usage rates ranging from 5 out of 28 roosts in one study to 31–67% in another (1935). Additionally, one review found that 81% of licensees did not carry out post-development monitoring (1935).

No studies were found that evaluated the effects of legally protecting bat species on bat populations in general (2037).

  "action_id": "1935",
  "action_title": "Legally protect bats during development",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Four studies evaluated the effects of legally protecting bats by issuing licences during development on bat populations. The four studies were in the UK.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (2 STUDIES)

Change in human behaviour (2 studies): One review in the UK found that the number of development licences for bats more than doubled over three years in Scotland. One review in the UK found that 81% of licensees did not carry out post-development monitoring to assess whether bats used the roost structures installed.

OTHER (3 STUDIES) 

Impact on bat roost sites (3 studies): One review in the UK found that licenced activities during building developments had a negative impact on bat roosts, with 68% of roosts being destroyed. One replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found that five of 28 compensation roosts provided under licence were used, and two by similar or greater numbers of bats after development. One review in the UK found that 31–67% of compensation roosts provided under licence were used by bats."
}

Five studies evaluated the effects of legally protecting bat habitats on bat populations. Four studies were in Europe and one was in India.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in India found that the composition of bat species was similar in protected forest and unprotected forest fragments.
Richness/diversity (2 studies): Two replicated, site comparison or paired sites studies in Europe and India found that the number of bat species did not differ between protected and unprotected forests or forest fragments. One replicated, site comparison study in France found that protected sites had a greater number of bat species than unprotected sites.

POPULATION RESPONSE (4 STUDIES)

Abundance (4 studies): One replicated, site comparison study in the UK found that the activity (relative abundance) of Daubenton’s bats was higher over rivers on farms in protected areas than in unprotected areas. One replicated, paired sites study in Europe found that the activity of common noctule bats was higher in protected forests than unprotected forests, but bat activity overall did not differ. Two replicated, site comparison studies in France and India found higher overall bat activity, higher activity of three of six bat species/species groups and a greater number of bats in protected sites and forests than unprotected sites and forests.

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)         

Use (1 study): One study in Spain found that the distributions of 10 of 11 bat species overlapped with areas designated to protect them significantly more than by chance."
}

query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of installing gates to restrict public access to subterranean bat roosts?
relevant_summary:
Following a review of actions related to installing gates to restrict public access to subterranean bat roosts, a summary of the documented benefits and negative impacts has been compiled.

Eleven studies evaluated the effects of installing cave gates on bat populations (999). Three of four before-and-after studies found more or similar numbers of bats in caves and a bunker after gates were installed to restrict public access (999). Two before-and-after studies found more bats within two caves after the size of the gated entrances were increased (999). One replicated, before-and-after study found that installing cave gates resulted in population increases or decreased rates of decline for 13 of 20 colonies of Indiana bat (999). However, one site comparison study found that bats hibernating in a cave with a wall and gate over the entrance lost more body mass than bats in a nearby unmodified cave (999). In terms of behavioural changes, one study found that bats at cave entrances circled more and entered caves less after gates were installed (999). Another study found that fewer bats flew through cave gates when the spacing between horizontal bars was reduced (999). A further study found that significantly fewer bats emerged from a cave with a gate installed compared with a cave with a fence (999). One replicated, site comparison study in Spain found no difference in the population growth rates or occupancy of bats roosting in caves with and without cave gates (999). One study did find fewer bats in caves after gates were installed (999). There were no studies found that evaluated the effects of providing artificial subterranean bat roosts to replace roosts in reclaimed mines or disturbed caves (974, 1005).

Eleven studies evaluated the effects of installing cave gates on bat populations. Six studies were in the USA and five studies were in Europe.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (7 STUDIES)

Abundance (7 studies): Three of four before-and-after studies (including one replicated study and one controlled study) in the Netherlands, the USA, Spain and Turkey found more or similar numbers of bats in caves and a bunker after gates were installed to restrict public access. The other study found fewer bats in caves after gates were installed. Two before-and-after studies in the USA and Spain found more bats within two caves after the size of the gated entrances were increased. One replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that installing cave gates resulted in population increases or decreased rates of decline for 13 of 20 colonies of Indiana bat. One replicated, site comparison study in Spain found no difference in the population growth rates of bats roosting in caves with and without cave gates.

BEHAVIOUR (5 STUDIES)   

Use (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in Spain found no difference in the occupancy rates of bats roosting in caves with and without cave gates.
Behaviour change (4 studies): One replicated, controlled, before-and-after and site comparison study in the USA found that bats at cave entrances circled more and entered caves less after gates were installed. One replicated study in the USA found that bats flew through gates with a funnel design more frequently than gates with a round bar or angle iron design. One randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in the UK found that fewer bats flew through cave gates when the spacing between horizontal bars was reduced. One before-and-after study in the USA found that significantly fewer bats emerged from a cave with a gate installed compared with a cave with a fence."
}

query: In the agricultural sector, what are the observed effects of organic farming systems compared to conventional farming on bat populations?
relevant_summary: A comparison of organic and conventional farming systems on bat populations shows varied results. In terms of species richness, five of seven studies found no difference in the number of bat species between organic and non-organic farms, while two studies found more species on organic farms (961). One study found no difference in the composition of bat species between organic and non-organic farms (961), but another study looking at chemical use found that farms with low or no chemical inputs had different bat species compositions compared to those with high chemical inputs (2013). One study found a higher diversity of insect-eating bats on coffee plantations with few or no chemical inputs, but not for fruit and nectar-eating bats (2013). When considering bat abundance, five of nine studies found no difference in overall bat activity between organic and non-organic farms (961). However, four studies found higher overall bat activity on organic farms (961). Additionally, two studies found higher activity for *Myotis* species over water on organic farms (961), and one study found higher activity for two of three bat species over organic fields compared to conventional ones (961). Two studies showed that farms or grasslands with few or no chemical inputs had higher overall bat activity (2013). Finally, one study found that great fruit-eating bats in areas without chemical use had higher body weights and body condition scores (2013).

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "961",
  "action_title": "Use organic farming instead of conventional farming",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twelve studies evaluated the effects of using organic farming instead of conventional farming on bat populations. Eight studies were in Europe, two in the USA, one in Canada and one in Chile.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (7 STUDIES)

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, paired sites study in the USA found that the composition of bat species did not differ between organic and non-organic farms.
Richness/diversity (7 studies): Five of seven replicated, paired sites or site comparison studies in Europe, the USA, Canada and Chile found that the number of bat species did not differ between organic and non-organic farms. The other two studies found more bat species on organic farms than non-organic farms.

POPULATION RESPONSE (12 STUDIES)

Abundance (12 studies): Five of nine replicated, paired sites or site comparison studies in Europe, the USA, Canada and Chile found that overall bat activity (relative abundance) and common pipistrelle activity did not differ between organic and non-organic farms. The other four studies found higher overall bat activity, bat feeding activity, Brazilian free-tailed bat activity, and activity of four of seven bat species on organic farms than non-organic farms. Two replicated, paired sites and site comparison studies in the UK found higher activity of Myotis species over water and rivers on organic farms than non-organic farms, but no differences were found for other species or habitats. One replicated, site comparison study in France found higher activity for two of three bat species over organic fields than two of three types of conventionally managed fields.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

{
  "action_id": "2013",
  "action_title": "Reduce pesticide, herbicide or fertiliser use",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Four studies evaluated the effects of reducing pesticide, herbicide and fertiliser use on bat populations. One study was in each of Mexico, Portugal, Germany and Columbia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in Portugal found that farms using few or no chemicals had different compositions of bat species to farms using high chemical inputs.
Richness/diversity (2 studies): One site comparison study in Mexico found that coffee agroforestry plantations using few or no chemicals had a higher diversity of insect-eating bat species than plantations with high chemical inputs, but the diversity of fruit and nectar-eating bat species did not differ. One paired sites study in Germany recorded more bat species over grassland with moderate or no fertiliser applications than grassland with high fertiliser applications.

POPULATION RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Abundance (2 studies): Two site comparison or paired sites studies (one replicated) in Portugal and Germany found that farms or grasslands with few or no chemical inputs had higher overall bat activity (relative abundance) than those using high chemical inputs.
Condition (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in Columbia found that great fruit-eating bats captured in ‘silvopastoral’ areas that used no chemicals, along with agroforestry, had higher body weights and body condition scores than those in conventional farming areas that used chemicals.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

query: During building developments, what alternatives to bat exclusion have been studied to mitigate disturbance to roosts?
relevant_summary:
Studies have looked at alternatives to bat exclusion during building developments, including creating alternative roosts and relocating access points to existing roosts. 

Two replicated studies found that bats did not use any of the alternative roosts provided in bat houses or a purpose-built bat wall after exclusion from buildings (949). However, other studies found that bat boxes or bat lofts/barns were used by bats at 13–74% of development sites (949). Three of five before-and-after studies found that bat colonies used purpose-built roosts in higher or similar numbers after the original roosts were destroyed, while two studies found that bats used purpose-built roosts in lower numbers than the original roost (949). A review in the UK found that new bat boxes/lofts built to replace destroyed roosts were four times less likely to be used by returning bats than roosts retained during development (949).

Regarding relocating access points, one before-and-after study in Ireland found that fewer brown long-eared bats used a roost after the access points were relocated (946). Another before-and-after study in the UK found that few lesser horseshoe bats used an alternative access point with a ‘bend’ design to re-enter a roost in a building development, but the number of bats using the roost increased after an access point with a ‘straight’ design was installed (946).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"alternatives to bat exclusion in building developments"}

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (11 STUDIES)     

Use: (11 studies): Two replicated studies in the USA and UK found that bats did not use any of the alternative roosts provided in bat houses or a purpose-built bat wall after exclusion from buildings. Three studies (two replicated) in the USA and UK and one review in the UK found that bat boxes or bat lofts/barns were used by bats at 13–74% of development sites, and bat lofts/barns were used by maternity colonies at one of 19 development sites. Three of five before-and-after studies in Portugal, Ireland, Spain and the UK found that bat colonies used purpose-built roosts in higher or similar numbers after the original roosts were destroyed. The other two studies found that bats used purpose-built roosts in lower numbers than the original roost. One review in the UK found that new bat boxes/lofts built to replace destroyed roosts were four times less likely to be used by returning bats than roosts retained during development."
}

query: What factors are associated with the successful use of artificial bat roosts by bats?
relevant_summary: One study in Spain found that modifying artificial roosts in buildings to reduce internal temperatures resulted in an increase in the number of bats using them (2052). In the UK, a study found that heated bat boxes were utilized by common pipistrelle bats at one of seven locations, although no maternity colonies used them (2052). Another UK study observed that none of the twelve heated bat boxes installed in churches were occupied by displaced Natterer’s bats (2052). In Australia, a replicated study showed that eight of the sixteen artificial hollows created in trees, which had two different entrance designs, were used by long-eared bats for roosting (2047). Furthermore, a study in the UK documented a yearly increase in the number of bats using an artificial hibernaculum over a nine-year period after its construction (2049). Studies in both Germany and the UK have found that artificial hibernacula were used by as many as four different bat species (2049).

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Abundance (1 study): One before-and-after study in Spain found more bats in two artificial roosts within buildings after they had been modified to reduce internal roost temperatures.

BEHAVIOUR (2 STUDIES)

Use (2 studies): One replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found that heated bat boxes were used by common pipistrelle bats at one of seven sites, but none were used by maternity colonies. One replicated study in the UK found that none of the 12 heated bat boxes installed within churches were used by displaced Natterer’s bats."

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Four studies evaluated the effects of creating artificial caves or hibernacula for bats on bat populations. Two studies were in the UK and two were in Germany.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (4 STUDIES)

Uptake (1 study): One study in the UK found that the number of bats using an artificial hibernaculum increased in each of nine years after it was built.
Use (4 studies): One study in the UK found that an artificial cave was used by a small number of brown long-eared bats. Three studies in Germany and the UK found that artificial hibernacula were used by up to four bat species."
}

tools_called.args: {"summary":"One study in Spain found that modifying artificial roosts in buildings to reduce internal temperatures resulted in an increase in the number of bats using them (2052). In the UK, a study found that heated bat boxes were utilized by common pipistrelle bats at one of seven locations, although no maternity colonies used them (2052). Another UK study observed that none of the twelve heated bat boxes installed in churches were occupied by displaced Natterer’s bats (2052). In Australia, a replicated study showed that eight of the sixteen artificial hollows created in trees, which had two different entrance designs, were used by long-eared bats for roosting (2047). Furthermore, a study in the UK documented a yearly increase in the number of bats using an artificial hibernaculum over a nine-year period after its construction (2049). Studies in both Germany and the UK have found that artificial hibernacula were used by as many as four different bat species (2049).","action_ids":["2052","2047","2049"],"query":"What factors are associated with the successful use of artificial bat roosts by bats?"}

query: As an alternative to increasing turbine cut-in speeds, what other operational changes can reduce bat mortality at wind farms?
relevant_summary: Five of six studies found that preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds, also known as 'feathering', resulted in fewer bat fatalities (970). One study found that bat fatalities were reduced when turbine blades were slowed at low wind speeds (2939).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"operational changes to reduce bat mortality at wind farms"}
{"query_string":"alternatives to increasing turbine cut-in speeds to reduce bat mortality"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "970",
  "action_title": "Prevent turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds ('feathering')",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies evaluated the effects of preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds on bat populations. Five studies were in the USA and one was in Canada.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (6 STUDIES)

Survival (6 studies): Five of six studies (including five replicated, controlled studies and one before-and-after study) in the USA and Canada found that preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds (‘feathering’), or feathering along with increasing the wind speed at which turbines become operational (‘cut-in speed’) resulted in fewer bat fatalities than at conventionally operated turbines. The other study found that automatically feathering turbine blades at low wind speeds did not reduce bat fatalities.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

{
  "action_id": "2939",
  "action_title": "Slow rotation of turbine blades at low wind speeds",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One study evaluated the effects of slowing the rotation of turbine blades at low wind speeds on bat populations. The study was in Canada.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Survival (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Canada found that bat fatalities were reduced when turbine blades were slowed at low wind speeds.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

tools_called.args: {"summary":"Five of six studies found that preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds, also known as 'feathering', resulted in fewer bat fatalities (970). One study found that bat fatalities were reduced when turbine blades were slowed at low wind speeds (2939).","action_ids":["970","2939"],"query":"As an alternative to increasing turbine cut-in speeds, what other operational changes can reduce bat mortality at wind farms?"}

query: What conservation actions can be implemented to combat the spread and impact of white-nose syndrome in bats?
relevant_summary: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on bat populations of culling bats infected with white-nose syndrome (1012) or vaccinating bats against the white-nose syndrome pathogen (1011). Two studies in Canada and the USA evaluated treating bats with a probiotic bacterium for white-nose syndrome (2008). One study in Canada found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic at the time of infection increased survival in a laboratory, but treatment 21 days prior to infection did not (2008). A study in the USA found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic in a mine increased survival for free-flying bats, but not for bats in cages (2008). The Canadian study also found that bats treated with a probiotic at the time of infection had reduced symptoms, but bats treated 21 days prior had worse symptoms (2008). The US study found that caged bats treated with a probiotic had similar disease severity to untreated bats (2008).

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "2008",
  "action_title": "Treat bats for infection with white-nose syndrome",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies evaluated the effects of treating bats with a probiotic bacterium to reduce white-nose syndrome infection. One study was in Canada and one in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Survival (2 studies): One randomized, controlled study in Canada found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium at the time of infection with white-nose syndrome (but not 21 days prior) increased survival within cages in a laboratory. One randomized, controlled study in the USA found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium within a mine increased survival for free-flying bats, but not caged bats.
Condition (2 studies): One randomized, controlled study in Canada found that little brown bats caged in a laboratory and treated with a probiotic bacterium at the time of infection with white-nose syndrome had reduced symptoms of the disease, but bats treated 21 days prior to infection had worse symptoms. One randomized, controlled study in the USA found that little brown bats kept within cages in a mine and treated with a probiotic bacterium had a similar severity of white-nose syndrome to untreated bats.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

Two studies in Canada and the USA evaluated treating bats with a probiotic bacterium for white-nose syndrome (2008). One study in Canada found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic at the time of infection increased survival in a laboratory, but treatment 21 days prior to infection did not (2008). A study in the USA found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic in a mine increased survival for free-flying bats, but not for bats in cages (2008). The Canadian study also found that bats treated with a probiotic at the time of infection had reduced symptoms, but bats treated 21 days prior had worse symptoms (2008). The US study found that caged bats treated with a probiotic had similar disease severity to untreated bats (2008)."}
